Graphical abstract Highlights ► LaMnO3 achieved an ideal performance for low-temperature NO-SCR by NH3. ► The ability of perovskites for NH3 adsorption plays a ruling role on NO reduction. ► The SCR reaction follows L–H mechanism involving nitrite and NH4 + species. In order to investigate the activities of perovskite-type mixed oxides for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3, a series of LaBO3 or La2BO4 perovskite-based catalysts with different B-site ions (B=Cu, Co, Mn, and Fe) was prepared by citrate complexation procedure and characterized by XRD, BET, TPD of NO+O2 and NH3. It was found that Mn-based perovskite exhibited the best catalytic activity, yielding 78% NO conversion at 250°C. The NH3 adsorption ability of the perovskites is the key factor for the SCR performance. In situ DRIFTS investigation was further carried out over LaMnO3 to explore the reaction mechanism. It is revealed that the SCR reaction starts with NH3 chemical adsorption, being thought as the rate-determining step. The mechanism essentially involves a Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism mainly depending on an interaction between NH4 + ionic species and nitrite species in the low-temperature range. Keywords In situ DRIFTS Low temperature Manganese Perovskites SCR of NO with NH3 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction with NH3 as a reductant (NH3-SCR) has been applied to reduce NO x emissions from the stationary sources for several decades [1]. Generally, in order to avoid the catalyst deactivation caused by the high concentration of ash and SO2 poison, the SCR unit is suggested to be located at the downstream of the electrostatic precipitator and desulfurizer [2]. As a result, the flue gas temperatures are commonly below 200°C or even lower [3]. The commercial catalyst used for this process, V2O5–WO3 (MoO3)/TiO2, shows a satisfactory performance, however, the reaction temperature is limited in a narrow and relatively higher range (300–400°C) [4]. Therefore, the development of the SCR catalysts with superior activities at lower temperatures for avoiding the high cost of reheating the flue gas has attracted lots of attention from the scientific academy. In recent years, the hotspots of the catalyst researches for SCR of NO with NH3 are mainly focused on the metal oxides and zeolites [5]. Tang et al. studied single MnO x oxides prepared by three kinds of methods [6], and Liu et al. also reported FeTiO x catalysts achieved good SCR performance [7]. Additionally, MnO x –CeO2 [8,9], Fe–Mn [10], Ce–Ti [11], and Ce–P–O [12] catalysts were investigated by many researchers. Moreover, a variety of supports such as TiO2 [3,13–15], Al2O3 [16], and AC (active carbon) catalysts [1,2,17,18] was proposed to load Mn-, Ce- and Fe-based oxides for the better SCR activities. As for the zeolite catalysts, copper ion-exchanged zeolites used for SCR have been reported by Yahiro and Iwamoto [19]. Generally speaking, ZSM-5 zeolites were commonly used to support the Fe-, Cu-, and Mn-containing oxides for selective catalytic NO reduction [20–22]. Perovskites, the promising catalysts for air pollutants purification due to the excellent thermal stability, superior redox properties, great versatility and low cost [23], seem to be the ideal candidates for the SCR of NO with NH3 at low-temperature region. Perovskite-type mixed oxides with a general ABO3 formula are well known that their physicochemical properties can be effectively modified by partial substitution of A- and/or B-site cations. Although lots of work for the low-temperature NH3-SCR process has been done, none was related to use perovskites as catalytic materials according to our knowledge. In this study, a series of perovskite catalysts with different B-site cations (B=Cu, Co, Mn, and Fe) was synthesized by the citrate complexation procedure and further characterized by N2 physisorption, temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 (or NO+O2). Based on the best-performing (the highest NO conversion) LaMnO3, in situ DRIFTS was performed for a better understanding of reaction mechanism for the low-temperature SCR of NO by NH3 occurring over perovskites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The preparation of all perovskite catalysts including LaBO3 (B-Mn, Fe, Co) and La2BO4 (B-Cu) was carried out by complexation method using citric acid as a complexation agent [24]. The individual metal nitrates were used as the precursors for A-site or B-site cations. The molar ratio of total metallic ions to citric acid was 1:1. The mixture of different required metal nitrates in stoichiometric amounts was initially dissolved in the distilled water. Thereafter, a solution containing citric acid in water was slowly added into the precursor solution under gentle stirring at 80°C until a gel was obtained. This gel was finally transferred to oven for drying at 110°C for 24h. Self-combustion was caused by setting fire to the dry gel in order to get the spongy residues. After a calcination of these residues at 600°C, all the obtained solids were crushed and sieved to 40–60 mesh for the following characterization and activity evaluation. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out using X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα (λ =0.15406nm) (Rigaku, D/max 2500VB2) in the range of 20–80° at a scan rate of 0.05° per second. The crystal phase and symmetry were confirmed through JCPDS reference. A static nitrogen adsorption equipment JW-RB24 was used to measure the specific surface area of the samples at liquid N2 temperature (−196°C) with outgas pretreatment at 200°C under vacuum. Before the NO+O2-TPD and NH3-TPD experiments, the samples (50mg) were pretreated in a flow of 1000ppm NO/He+6% O2 or 1000ppm NH3/He at 200°C for 1h. After the samples were cooled down to room temperature (30°C) under the same atmosphere, the stream was switched to the He flow (20mL/min) for another hour to remove the physically adsorbed species. Then, the temperature was raised linearly to 500°C at a rate of 5°C/min. NO, NO2 and N2O desorbed during NO+O2-TPD experiments were simultaneously detected and on-line recorded using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (OmniStar, MS200) with m/z =30, 46 and 44, respectively. Moreover, during NH3-TPD experiments the signals of m/z =16, 30, 44 and 46 were monitored for NH2, NO, N2O and NO2 fragments. In situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted on a FTIR spectrometer (TENSOR 27, Bruker) equipped with a MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen and a diffuse reflection accessory (Praying Mantis, Harrick) which carries a high temperature reaction chamber. This accessory is attached to an automatic temperature controller (Harrick) which controls precisely the temperature of reaction chamber. After the sample was placed into the reaction chamber under He flow (20mL/min), the temperature was raised to 200°C. As the background spectrum was collected and the baseline of spectrum was stabilized, the He flow was cut off and the feeding gases were introduced into the chamber. IR spectra were recorded by accumulating 64 scans at a spectrum resolution of 4cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The NH3-SCR of NO was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor in the temperature range of 100–400°C by a step of 50°C. The reaction was performed in a flow of 100mL/min (given a GHSV of 30,000h−1), composed of 1000ppm NO, 1000ppm NH3, 6% O2, and balanced with He, over 200mg of each sample. The contents of the gas components (NO, NH3, N2O, and NO2) were analyzed by an infrared gas analyzer (Nicolet Nexus 470). N2 was determined using a gas chromatograph (GC, HP 5890) fitted with TCD and columns of 5A and TDX-01. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structure and specific surface area The XRD patterns of perovskites with the diverse B-site cations are shown in Fig. 1 . A comparison of these spectra with JCPDS charts indicated that this series of LaBO3 (B=Fe, Mn and Co) samples was nearly pure perovskite-type structure. LaCoO3 presented a rhombohedral symmetry (JCPDS card 86-1662). Similarly, pure cubic LaFeO3 (JCPDS card 75-0541) and rhombohedral LaMnO3.15 (JCPDS card 50-0298) perovskite-type structure were also confirmed by XRD patterns. Since the preparation of LaCuO3 was found to be difficult, in our present work La2CuO4, having a special structure of A2BO4, was synthesized successfully at 600°C, and performed an orthorhombic symmetry of perovskite structure (JCPDS card 82-2142). The physical properties of prepared samples are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that Mn-based perovskite showed a relatively higher surface area than those of other perovskites, resulting a decreasing order of LaMnO3 (36.5m2 g−1)>LaFeO3 (32.7m2 g−1)>LaCoO3 (24.3m2 g−1)>La2CuO4 (23.3m2 g−1). It is common knowledge that an increase in surface areas of heterogeneous catalysts is beneficial for an enhancement in their reactivities. Considering the latter activity data, the contribution from the enhancement in surface areas on NO conversion was thought to be rather limited in comparison with the chemical properties of perovskites. 3.2 NO x and NH3 adsorption abilities Fig. 2a illustrates the desorption signals of NO (m/z =30) and NO2 (m/z =46) as a function of temperature during the NO+O2-TPD process over all the perovskite samples. A quantitative analysis based on the deconvolution and integration of these desorption peaks is listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that in the low-temperature region of 50–200°C, NO desorption could be detected only over LaMnO3 and LaCoO3. Two medium NO peaks centered at about 200°C and 317°C over LaCoO3 were observed, as well as a weak peak at >400°C. Surprisingly, NO desorption could be always monitored over LaMnO3 throughout the whole temperature range (70–500°C), particularly at about 380°C, where a board and strong desorption peak presented. While NO desorptions over La2CuO4 and LaFeO3 initially started at around 225°C and 200°C, respectively, and each of them performed several obvious and broad peaks within the high-temperature range (>250°C), especially for La2CuO4. The individual dotted lines representing NO2 (m/z =46) fragment displayed a nearly similar shape like the corresponding NO curves apart from a slight delay on the initiation temperature. The N2O desorption curves attained over all perovskites are presented in Fig. S2 of Supporting Information. MS signals of NH3 (m/z =16) and NO (m/z =30) during the NH3-TPD process after an adsorption at 200°C are showed in Fig. 2b. The amounts of NH3 and NO desorbed from all perovskites are quantified and reported in Table 3 . The NH3 desorption peaks for all the samples were clearly observed below 100°C, and the desorption amounts of NH3 diminished gradually at the elevated temperatures. Simultaneously, the desorption of considerable amounts of NO was also observed, as represented by the dotted lines. Therefore, it is inferred that the adsorbed NH3 can be readily oxidized into NO x upon perovskites. As for the NO signal, it could be desorbed at about 300°C for all samples expect for LaCoO3, of which the NO signal emerged at a relatively lower temperature of 150°C and then exhibited a sharp peak at 258°C. NO2 and N2O desorption curves over all perovskites from NH3-TPD are illustrated in Fig. S3 of Supporting Information. 3.3 SCR activity evaluation The SCR activities of Cu-, Co-, Mn-, and Fe-based perovskites as functions of temperature are given in Fig. 3 . As seen from Fig. 3a, which depicts NO conversions over four catalysts in SCR reaction, LaMnO3 exhibited the best deNO x activity among these samples, yielding 78% NO conversion at 250°C and a space velocity of ∼30,700h−1. As noted, the NO conversion tended to decrease as the temperature exceeded 300°C. However, it is worthy to notice that the superior performance of LaMnO3 has already been achieved in a broad low-temperature range, which could be illustrated by NO conversion keeping >65% in 200–350°C. LaFeO3 just showed a rather poor activity for SCR process in the whole temperature region (100–400°C), always exhibiting the NO conversion below 25%. LaCoO3 did not display any activity until 200°C, and lasted for a narrow temperature window. Compared with LaFeO3 and LaCoO3, La2CuO4 performed a better NO conversion, exhibiting 45% NO conversion at 250°C (approximately 50°C lower than that of LaCoO3). NH3 conversions, another important parameter to evaluate the SCR performance, are illustrated in Fig. 3b. NH3 conversion for each sample enhanced simultaneously with the increasing temperature, even if the corresponding NO conversion strongly declined above 250°C or higher, implying the seriously direct oxidation of NH3 in the high-temperature zone, instead of the participation of SCR process. LaMnO3 achieved the best NH3 conversion at the whole temperature range, and complete conversion was obtained above 350°C. Conversion was detected to be low at 100 and 150°C over LaCoO3, but it was intensely improved above 200°C associated with values higher than those of La2CuO4. In the case of LaFeO3, NH3 conversion maintained to be the lowest among the tested materials. The selectivities toward N2, NO2 and N2O for all the investigated perovskites are described in Fig. S4a–c of Supporting Information. Unfortunately, the selectivity of N2 declined along with the increasing temperatures over all the materials, especially for LaCoO3 and LaMnO3, with the appearances of abundant N2O and NO2 byproducts respectively at medium and high temperatures. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS 3.4.1 NO+O2 co-adsorption on LaMnO3 as well as the reaction between NH3 and adsorbed NO x species In order to elucidate the SCR mechanism over perovskites, the best performing LaMnO3 was selected for the related in situ DRIFTS study. Fig. 4a shows the DRIFT spectra of LaMnO3 exposed to an atmosphere of 1000ppm NO+6% O2 at 200°C for various times and after He purge for 20min. With the introduction of NO+O2 stream into the IR chamber for several minutes, a range of weak bands at 1295, 1395, 1467, 1535, 1630, 1794, 1844 and 1906cm−1 was detected. The intensities of the bands located at 1395, 1467, 1794, 1844, and 1906cm−1 grew with the contact time very slowly, while the bands at 1295, 1535 and 1630cm−1 increased remarkably within the first 10min, then developed gently afterwards. At 15min, a new band located at 1353cm−1 appeared and increased so acutely that the band at 1395cm−1 merged swiftly into its shoulder. After purging by He for 20min, the bands at 1630, 1794, 1844 and 1906cm−1 disappeared completely. According to the literature assignment, the two bands at 1844 and 1906cm−1 are ascribed to weakly adsorbed NO (mononitrosyl species) [25,26] and the band at 1794cm−1 is due to cis-(NO)2 (dinitrosyl species) [25]. Additionally, the band at 1630cm−1 could be attributed to weakly adsorbed NO2 [25,27]. Moreover, the two strong bands at 1295 and 1535cm−1 are likely due to bidentate nitrate species [9,26,28,29], while the small bands at 1395 and 1467cm−1 are assigned to monodentate nitrite species (ONO−) [9,30]. The strong band at 1353cm−1, according to previous reports [25,31], is attributed to cis-hyponitrite (cis-N2O2 2−). The DRIFT spectra of 1000ppm NH3 flushing LaMnO3 covered with the primarily adsorbed NO x species are illustrated in Fig. 4b. After NH3 purge at 200°C, no new bands related to the adsorbed NH3 species was detected, and the adsorbed NO x species had no obvious diminution, but there was a slight increase in the intensity of the band at 1295cm−1 due to bidentate nitrate. This phenomenon implies a very strong adsorption of NO x species on LaMnO3, resulting in few active sites left for the subsequent NH3 adsorption at 200°C. Considering the NH3-TPD results that NH3 adsorbed on LaMnO3 can be partially oxidized into NO x species, it is speculated that the slight enhancement of bidentate nitrate species is probably due to the oxidation of NH3 upon the limited sites left for further adsorption. 3.4.2 NH3 adsorption on LaMnO3 as well as the reaction between NO+O2 and adsorbed NH3 species In Fig. 5a the DRIFT spectra of the species arising from the contact of LaMnO3 with gaseous ammonia at 200°C are reported. A range of weak bands located at 1393, 1425, 1462, 1510, 1595, 1642, 1697cm−1 and a moderate band at 1559cm−1 were observed immediately after an introduction of NH3 for 1min. The two bands at 1425 and 1462cm−1 increased obviously in their intensities, and rapidly merged into a new band at 1438cm−1 at 6min, which developed significantly with the contact time. Both of the two bands at 1559 and 1595cm−1 grew swiftly, but the other bands increased slowly upon the exposure time. After He purge for 20min, the band at 1559cm−1 became sharper and stronger. Based on the previous studies about the assignment of adsorbed NH3 species, three IR bands at 1425, 1438 and 1462cm−1 can be attributed to the asymmetric deformation of NH4 + [δ as(NH4 +)] bound to Brönsted acid sites [9,32]. The strong band at 1595cm−1 and the weak band at 1697cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric deformation of NH3 [δ as(NH3)] coordinated to Lewis acid sites [9,32,33] and δ s(NH4 +) bound to Brönsted acid sites [7,32], respectively. While the bands at 1393, 1510, 1559 and 1642cm−1, in the light of the ability of LaMnO3 for NH3 oxidation previously mentioned by some researchers [9], probably does not belong to any adsorbed NH3 species but ONO− [30], monodentate nitrate [26], bidentate nitrate [9] and bridging nitrate species [29,31], respectively. Besides, the increasing of bidentate nitrate after He purge is likely caused by a transform from surface NH3, together with a decline of the band at 1595cm−1. The spectra of LaMnO3 pretreated by 1000ppm NH3 with a further exposure to 1000ppm NO+6% O2 at 200°C are presented in Fig. 5b. After the introduction of NO+O2 for 1min, the band intensity of coordinated NH3 (1595cm−1) decreased. Simultaneously, a new band at 1607cm−1 corresponded to bridging nitrate [7,33] was observed and increased along with the time. At 3min, the coordinated NH3 species was thoroughly consumed, and the δ as(NH4 +) species (1438cm−1) also decreased quickly. Additionally, a new band at 1453cm−1 corresponding to monodentate nitrite [9] appeared after 3min and grew sharply, which was accompanied with the two bands at 1393 and 1510cm−1 rising. Up to 20min, the δ as(NH4 +) species were entirely consumed, and the δ s(NH4 +) species (1697cm−1) also had an obvious decrease. The nitrite–nitrate species (1393, 1453 and 1510cm−1) significantly increased, and the gaseous NO (1907, 1843cm−1) were observed. With time prolonging, the growing band at 1510cm−1 had entirely merged with the band at 1559cm−1 into a new strong band located at 1525cm−1, which is due to bidentate nitrate species [26]. Interestingly, the two bands at 1607 and 1642cm−1 had the same behavior, causing the formation of an intense band at 1625cm−1, which is attributed to the bridging nitrate species [7,32]. The analysis on DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption on LaMnO3 reveals that (1) all of δ as(NH4 +) and δ s(NH4 +) bound to Brönsted acid sites, coordinated δ as(NH3) adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, and some nitrite–nitrate species due to the oxidation of adsorbed NH3, can form on the surface of LaMnO3 after NH3 adsorption; (2) both the coordinated NH3 and ionic NH4 + could participate into the SCR reaction; (III) the amount of NH4 + ions is likely larger than that of coordinated NH3, which could be verified by the an area comparison between the sole peak at 1438cm−1 (NH4 +) with the shoulder peak at 1595cm−1 (coordinated NH3). 3.4.3 NH3 +NO+O2 co-adsorption on LaMnO3 The formation of surface species on LaMnO3 under an atmosphere simulating to a real SCR process (NO+O2 +NH3) is also investigated via DRIFTS as presented in Fig. 6 . After exposure for 1min, all the bridging nitrate (1646cm−1) [9,33], bidentate nitrate (1294 and 1555cm−1) [7,9,26], cis-N2O2 2− (1344cm−1) [31,34], nitrite (1399 and 1446cm−1) [9,30], and δ as(NH4 +) species (1417cm−1) [32] were observed immediately. The amount of δ as(NH4 +) species was minor, and they could react with NO x species rapidly. The weak band at 1606cm−1 might be assigned to δ as(NH3) [32] and/or bridging nitrate species [9]. From 5min to 40min, the IR peaks of these species listed above, except for δ as(NH4 +), increased to the different extents, and no more new bands emerged. As analyzed above, it is obtained that the reaction between NO x and NH3 species is very rapid, and the amount of adsorbed NH3 species is smaller than those of nitrites and nitrates, which was attributed to the competitive adsorption between NO x and NH3 upon LaMnO3 and the deeply catalytic oxidation of NH3 to NO x . Therefore, it can be found that the adsorbed NH3 species amounts are crucial for the SCR process occurring over perovskites, resulting in the effective adsorption of ammonia being an important step for NO selective reduction. 3.5 The correlation among TPD, activity evaluation and DRIFTS experiments According to the in situ DRIFTS study (Fig. 4a), the formed NO x species upon LaMnO3 included nitrosyl and nitrite–nitrate species after NO adsorption. Furthermore, Isupova et al. [35] revealed that nitrite–nitrate, mononitrosyl, and dinitrosyls species could be detected over LaFeO3, LaCoO3 and LaMnO3 perovskites. And the NO2 curves in Fig. 2a also confirmed the formation of nitrite–nitrate species upon perovskites. Additionally, our early study [36] had proposed that thermal stability of NO x species followed an order of nitrosyl species (N2+)<nitrite (N3+)<nitrate (N5+). During NO+O2-TPD processes, it therefore could be deduced that the NO desorption peaks in the low temperature range (<200°C) for all perovskites should be ascribed to the nitrosyls species and some nitrite species with lower stability. Obviously, only Co- and Mn-based perovskites could achieve the active nitrosyls and nitrite species in low-temperature range as seen from Table 2. While, the amount of NO x species adsorbed on La2CuO4 was the largest, but the NO x signals were observed above 250°C, implying these species upon Cu-based perovskite are highly stable nitrate species, which is consistent with Liu et al.’s report [37]. From the NH3-TPD and DRIFTS results, one point is clarified that NH3 adsorbed on perovskite catalysts in the forms of NH4 + ions and coordinated NH3, which are appearing on the surface at low temperatures, together with some nitrite–nitrate species due to the oxidation of surface NH3 occurring at relatively high temperatures. Fig. 6 has concluded that the amounts of adsorbed NH3 species formed over perovskites are crucial for SCR of NO with NH3. Hence, correlating the discussion above with the activity data, the following conclusions can be drawn: (1) LaMnO3 and La2CuO4 achieved almost the same amounts of adsorbed NH3 species (12.38μmolg−1 and 11.08μmolg−1, respectively, Table 3). But, the former one exhibited a certain amount of NO x species (mainly ascribed to nitrosyl and nitrite species) below 200°C during NO+O2-TPD, while the latter displayed none in the same temperature region (Table 2). Furthermore, much better NO conversion was obtained over LaMnO3 than La2CuO4 at low temperatures (Fig. 3a). Therefore, it can be concluded that the active nitrosyl and nitrites species are the principal NO x species which participated into SCR reaction over the low-temperature region. (2) The amounts of NO x species over LaMnO3 and LaCoO3 are very close as reported in Table 2, whereas the amounts of adsorbed NH3 species over the two catalysts are quite different (12.38μmolg−1 for LaMnO3, 7.79μmolg−1 for LaCoO3, Table 3). Similarly, combining these analyses with the activity comparison between LaMnO3 and LaCoO3 (NO conversions of 70% and below 5% at 200°C, respectively, Fig. 3a), it is speculated that the ability of perovskite for NH3 adsorption makes a great impact on the SCR reactivity, in accordance with the conclusions deduced from the DRIFTS experiments. 3.6 SCR mechanism over LaMnO3 at 200°C The mechanism of SCR of NO with NH3 at low temperature over various catalysts including Fe- and Mn-based catalyst has been discussed by many researchers [7,25,32,33,38,39]. Different hypotheses have been proposed, including the reaction between an amide and gaseous NO, the reaction between ammonium ion and adsorbed NO2, and the gas-phase reaction of NH3 and NH4 + with NO. Liu [7] proposed a Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) mechanism for SCR over FeTiO x in the low-temperature range (<200°C), in which the reactive surface species are mainly NH4 + and monodentate nitrate, and an Eley–Rideal (E–R) mechanism occurring at high temperatures (>200°C), in which the reactive species is mainly NH2 and the formation of NH2NO intermediate species is the rate-determining step. Kijlstra et al. [39] also studied the mechanism for SCR of NO with NH3 at low temperature over MnO x /Al2O3 catalyst, indicating the reaction starts with the adsorption of NH3 on Lewis acid sites and subsequently transforms into NH2, which would then react with gas phase NO (E–R mechanism) and nitrite intermediates on the surface (L–H mechanism). In our research, it has been concluded that the active species upon LaMnO3 perovskite over the low-temperature region are nitrosyls and nitrite species, but the amount of nitrosyls is much smaller than that of nitrite species at 200°C according to Fig. 4a. Therefore, it could be deduced that at 200°C the main NO x species which participated into SCR reaction on surface of LaMnO3 should be nitrite species. Additionally, the marginal change of adsorbed NO x species on LaMnO3 after an introduction of NH3 (Fig. 4b) suggests the SCR reaction initiates with the chemical adsorption of NH3 over LaMnO3. Moreover, the rapid consumption of adsorbed NH3 species after the introduction of NO+O2 (Fig. 5b) implies that both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites could participate into the SCR reaction, with the NH4 + species bound to Brönsted acid sites predominating at 200°C. Imbihl revealed a L–H mechanism for CO oxidation on a platinum group metal surface by changing the partial pressure of CO in this reaction [40]. Luo et al. also reported a typical L–H mechanism for NH3-SCR of NO over Fe-beta zeolite by changing NO or NH3 concentration in SCR tests [41]. Similar experiments were carried out at 150°C and NO conversions in different NO/NH3 concentrations (200–1000ppm) were recorded, in order to confirm L–H mechanism in this study. The effect of NO concentration is presented in Fig. 7a, and a parabolic NO conversion is observed, with an optimum NO concentration of 600ppm. Below 600ppm, NO conversion almost linearly increased upon its concentration. When NO was insufficient (<600ppm), the largely higher concentration of NH3 (1000ppm) led to much higher adNH3/NH4 + coverage ratio on the surface of LaMnO3 with respect to adNO x , resulting in NH3 inhibition and lower NO conversion. 600ppm of NO was obviously in favor of this SCR process, leading to suitable surface coverage ratios of adNO x and adNH3/NH4 + at this temperature. However, with more NO input, the corresponding conversion declined rapidly, indicating that there was excessive adNO x coverage in comparison with adNH3/NH4 +, as observed in DRIFTS (Fig. 6, NONH3 =1000ppm, exhibiting much better NO adsorption ability), leading to insufficient surface NH3 species for this SCR. Therefore, NO concentrations above 600ppm resulted in NO inhibition instead of NH3 one. Such a parabolic conversion of NO clearly shows the competitive adsorption between NO and NH3 on Mn n+ involving a typical L–H mechanism [41]. In the case of changing NH3 concentration (Fig. 7b), slight activity improvement (<5%) was obtained from 200ppm to 1000ppm of NH3. It can be reasonably attributed to a limited increase of adNH3/NH4 + coverage until 1000ppm, showing again the much better adsorption ability of NO than NH3. Therefore, a L–H mechanism for the SCR reaction of NO with NH3 over LaMnO3 catalyst at low temperature is proposed herein in the following pathway: gaseous NH3 is firstly adsorbed on the surface of LaMnO3 mainly in the form of NH4 + ions, NO x is simultaneously adsorbed on LaMnO3 in the forms of nitrosyl species, which later can be oxidized to nitrite and nitrate species. Subsequently, the NH4 + species will react with the active nitrites to produce the unstable ammonium nitrite for a further N2 generation. 4 Conclusions LaMnO3 perovskite exhibited the best catalytic activity in the SCR of NO using NH3 among all the tested samples prepared by citrate complexation method, yielding 78% NO conversion at 250°C at a space velocity of 30,000h−1, and it increased along with the reaction temperature in the range of 100–300°C. The amount of adsorbed NH3 plays a ruling role in SCR reaction, because of the relatively weak ability of perovskites to adsorb NH3 caused by a competitive adsorption between NO and NH3 and an easy oxidation of adsorbed NH3 to NO x . The low-temperature SCR process likely starts with a chemical adsorption of NH3, deemed as the rate-determining step, and follows a Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism, in which the mainly reaction species are nitrite and NH4 + ionic species. coredata.dc:description: In order to investigate the activities of perovskite-type mixed oxides for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3, a series of LaBO3 or La2BO4 perovskite-based catalysts with different B-site ions (B=Cu, Co, Mn, and Fe) was prepared by citrate complexation procedure and characterized by XRD, BET, TPD of NO+O2 and NH3. It was found that Mn-based perovskite exhibited the best catalytic activity, yielding 78% NO conversion at 250°C. The NH3 adsorption ability of the perovskites is the key factor for the SCR performance. In situ DRIFTS investigation was further carried out over LaMnO3 to explore the reaction mechanism. It is revealed that the SCR reaction starts with NH3 chemical adsorption, being thought as the rate-determining step. The mechanism essentially involves a Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism mainly depending on an interaction between NH4 + ionic species and nitrite species in the low-temperature range.
coredata.dc:title: Low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 using perovskite-type oxides as the novel catalysts
